三.kun_translate: (also sometimes pronounced み＊っつ) three things. Yes, it's got 2 pronunciations

女.kun_translate: woman - but don't say it by itself, it's like saying 'That broad.'

否.kun_translate: 'No'. Usually used by older people. Or pretentious authors, who contradict themselves for rhetorical effect: 'She was a proper woman, No, wait, perhaps I should rather say she was the kind of woman who wanted to be seen as proper, A-ha-ha, I am so clever.'

十.kun_translate: (also　pronounced just と）meaning, 'ten things'.  Yes, it has two pronunciations!

叶.kun_translate: one's dream comes true. Usually used like this: 夢が叶う-ゆめがかなう： my dream comes true!

計.kun_translate: suffix meaning, the total xxx. Total hours, total pounds, total hogs-heads, etc.

旨.kun_translate: this is a really good word, meaning 'delicious!' or 'well done!'

唱.kun_translate: bunch of people chanting or reciting in unison - also, one person muttering something over and over in a creepy way.

早.kun_translate: early, as in, 'get up early.'　BOOBOO: this doesn't mean fast! that's the other  hayai (速い）

泉.kun_translate: spring, as in water popping out of the earth

汁.kun_translate: SUFFIX which means juice, or soup (as in味噌汁：みそしる； (miso soup)) , . . .also semen

混.kun_translate: I blend the ingredients (BOOBOO: unlike the other まぜる　（交ぜる）, this word is used for technical stuff- science or cooking.

明.kun_translate: bright , sunny weather / person with a sunny disposition.

炎.kun_translate: a big fire, but not a harmful one. Like a campfire or bonfire

淡.kun_translate: faint color. (薄い also means faint, but 淡い carries the connotation of, it's faint because it's weak or sickly)

田.kun_translate: Only used in peoples' names: 田中(たなか） is the Japanese version of Smith.

町.kun_translate: a small town -  but also a SUFFIX which means xxx-town. Like Levittown or Funkytown.

畑.kun_translate: SUFFIX meaning, "field of a particular crop". like いちご はたけ、(field of strawberries) or すいか はたけ (field of watermelons). You don't need an article like 'no' or 'na'.  .You know what? It's weird that we don't have a word for this in English.

入.kun_translate: I put it in (I put the dog in the doghouse)

何.onyomi: KA, but you don't need to learn it.

化.kun_translate: transform - this is ONLY used in the context of a person changing to a ghost, or a curse transforming a person into a werewolf. In other words, it is not used that often.

苦.kun_translate: bitter taste ー medicine, okra. Can also be used figuratively - the bitter taste of defeat.

草.kun_translate: grass - tall, uncut grass.(BOOBOO: In practice, though, most people use　芝生 (しばふ）)

内.kun_translate: inside a thing, OR inside of a certain time frame(eat it while it's hot! 温かい内に食べて!) Also, it's a slang term for 'us.'

円.kun_translate: circircular　(not used! People use  the OTHER まるい　（丸い）  instead)

姉.kun_translate: someone else's older sister- or, if you're a sexist douche, you can use it about any young woman, in the sense of 'hey sweetheart, bring me more tea, chop chop!' (hence the ABU tag)

冒.kun_translate: to risk xxx (grave danger/ your life/ your anal virginity) doing crazy shit

自.kun_translate: to do something one's own self, in person

方.kun_translate: two meanings:  1) method. 2) a somewhat formal, polite term for　ｐｅｒｓｏｎ  (i.e. 日本の方 means 'a person from Japan')

訪.kun_translate: an important person visits another important person (an official state visit, visit the pope, etc.)

妨.kun_translate: obstruct /  hamper.  Unlike the related words 阻む (habamu) and 防ぐ (fusegu）, 妨げる  carries the nuance of 'interrupt' or 'disrupt', like 'The guys at the next table are hampering our conversation,' or 'The corporate extortionist kept interrupting the shareholders' meeting.'

奴.kun_translate: dood, homeboy, (can also be rude if he's not actually your homeboy and he hears you) - also an informal term for 'thing,' kind of like the spanish "ese." ("Pass me that thing, ese!")

済.kun_translate: to get through doing something (usually a chore or homework); to finally pay off debts. Sometimes used like this: ｘｘｘをすませる。('Finish your xxx!')

収.kun_translate: Can be used to mean "recive money" or "recieve a victory", but usually means "To load things in an organized manner." - cargo containers, for example.

叫.kun_translate: to exclaim! If you're surprised and go AAAAAA or HOLY COW WHAT THE HELL MAN, that's 叫ぶ。   Unlike the related word 喚く　（わめく） 叫ぶ is not always out of anger -you can use this for shouting slogans or screaming your friend's name.

心.kun_translate: heart, metaphorically. 'All my heart' and that kind of good shit.

思.kun_translate: To think (BOOBOO: 思う　should not be confused with the other 'think' (考える　（かんがえる））. 思う is like, "I think your Moms is the source of the fungus." "I think the theater is over there."  考える is more like thinking to solve a problem: thinking about physics or math.

亡.kun_translate: a polite way of saying die, like the English phrase  "pass on."

盲.kun_translate: ( don't use! it's a term of prejudice used against blind people)

上.kun_kanji:
うえ
(
の or に
)

点.kun_translate: a point, a dot.  This is used in 2 ways;   a) a dot like the decimal point. . . .actually the 4 dots at the bottom of this kanji are referred to as tens.  b) a point of conversation, as in "That's not the point and you know it!"

喧.kun_translate: annoying because noisy or loud - can be used of a person OR place.

沿.kun_translate: run parallel to, like a trail parallel to the edge of a lake, or a line of houses running alongside the train tracks.

治.kun_translate: I cure a disease or health problem 　(BOOBOO: if you want to fix an object, use the OTHER なおす kanji : 直す）

始.kun_translate: I begin to (take apart your lego portrait of Pee Wee Herman)

立.kun_translate: Something stands up; something is set up.

億.kun_translate: 100,000,000 , but be careful -- if you want to say "one hundred thousand", you have to put the 'ichi' in front, like so: 一億

間.kun_translate: an interval of time - the time between event A and event B.

問.kun_translate: to ask (BOOBOO: only used in a formal situation, where the wrong answer spells trouble: - the police questioned the suspect, the situation calls his authority into question)

召.kun_translate: summon (never used by itself! But you need it to say the following jukugo:)

照.kun_translate: to illuminate, literally, or in the (figurative) sense of comparing ２ things.

分.kun_translate: understand. (BOOBOO - Not 'understand' like 'I know the capital of Australia", but more like, "Oh! NOW I get it! DON'T call them skanks! ')

刃.kun_translate: BOOBOO: not a knife or sword - the BLADE or the SHARP EDGE of one. Remember, swords don't kill people, 刃s kill people.

忍.kun_translate: A very old word - from feudal times - not used anymore. It means "to endure or bear," but is usually used only in the context of bearing shame or disgrace.  The ninja connection of this kanji lies in the SECOND meaning , which is restricted to this one idiom: 人目を忍ぶ　（ひとめをしのぶ）, meaning, to do secretly , or to do without being seen.

努.kun_translate: make an effort (at improving your French, at quitting smoking, to be nice to your friend's douche boyfriend, etc.) , - Actualy, this is more in common with がんばるthan with the other two つとめるs.（勤めるand　務める）

究.kun_translate: to investigate until you are a master of something

熟.kun_translate: to ripen (used of plants or fruits)(which are plants).

執.kun_translate: to assume command of something, to take control of something, to spearhead some shit, and - randomly - to take up your pen and write some shit (which presumably the shit is a manifesto or expose or will start shit).

少.kun_translate: more positive than the the other one . . .more like, "do you want milk in your coffee?" "Just a little!"

劣.kun_kanji:
(
ガ or に
)
おと*る

妙.kun_translate: An unusual (but not enchanted or scary or supernatural) situation.

省.kun_translate: omit or　skip (skip the red tape, skip a step in the process, skip the rest of the kanji and go to bed , cut out unneccesary expenses )

涼.kun_translate: to be cool (there's a feeling of relief about this - usually said after a hot day or a hot summer)

示.kun_translate: to show or indicate.But you can't say 'I'll show you my wang.' Why? One, in that case , you're supposed to use 'miseru' instead, and two, you don't have a wang, you lost it in the war.  示す is more like "Studies indicate a link between yo mama and trench-mouth." Or "History shows again and again how nature points out the folly of man."

寂.kun_translate: lonely (BOOBOO: even though it's written saBIshii, most people pronounce it "saMIIshii!")

幼.kun_translate: childish, very young- cute if applied to a child, rude if applied to an immature adult.

蓄.kun_translate: setting stuff aside for a rainy day. Used about good stuff.

線.kun_translate: a literal line, like what you'd draw.

納.kun_translate: a really narrow, yet weird word: to pay taxes/school fees/bribes; or to place something in the place it's supposed to be: swords in scabbards, mummies in tombs.

係.kun_translate: to be involved with, to get caught up in,(usually in a bad thing)

干.kun_translate: to dry, but only in the narrow sense of hanging laundry out to dry.

用.kun_translate: To use. (More formal/scientific than つかう） As in, "Please use this pencil to complete the test.

肝.kun_translate: chutzpah, courage, pluck. (Westerners of either sex believe that their daring and courage live in their balls. Japanese believe it lives in the liver/gallbladder area!)

話.kun_translate: to chat (BOOBOO; If you want to ask someone if they speak Japanese, Don't ever say "nihongo hanaseru?"- that's strictly NOOB. say "Nihongo SHABERU?" instead)

憩.kun_translate: place for recreation and relaxation - 99% used in the following one expression: 憩いの場 (ikoi no basho).

半.kun_translate: in the middle, halfway (mid-30s, middle of June, mid-century)

判.kun_translate: A lot of dictionaries still say 判る is a synonym of 分かる. Not really. Don't bother learning 判る.

伴.kun_translate: accompany, in both literal and figurative sense: Bill accompanies Doug. But also, rain accompanies high winds at this time of year (notice how it doesn't care about cause and effect)

Also,　you use　里 when a wife leaves her husband - "She went back to the sato."

量.kun_translate: to measure an amount - used mostly about weight, but also quantity or volume.

童.kun_translate: an archaic, literary/poetic word for child. Usually seen on CDs for childrens' songs: わらべのうた。

憧.kun_translate: long for, yearn for (world domination, a soul-mate, revenge) (but usually a soul-mate)

坊.kun_translate: a casual way to refer to a monk

吐.kun_translate: puke (or, emit - as in, "The flaming building emitted gouts of smoke.")

吉.kun_translate: 90% of the time this is only used in fortune-telling. Usually used like this: 吉　（きち）(good omen) or 不吉な兆し　（ふきちなきざし）bad omen

結.kun_translate: tie a knot. tie your shoelaces.

老.kun_translate: to get old, a somewhat perjorative term: Danny Glover saying 'I'm too old for this shit!' - "Dumbledore's getting old, he makes mistakes."Also means "To be a kid but look older than you are."
老.kun_kanji:
(
に　・　を
)
ふ*けてる

著.kun_translate: remarkable, notable (a striking mismatch between two things, a marked decline in white blood cells, a significant effect on the disease, a glaring weakness, a marked success)

暑.kun_translate: hot weather, a place with a hot climate

煮.kun_translate: boil (potato) or simmer (a sauce or stew or onabe)

焦.kun_translate: to char  or scortch. Like char-broiled beef. Also, often used with hot, passionate emotions: burning with the fiiiire of looooooveeeee!!!!!!!!!!!!

無.kun_translate: SUFFIX which turns the previous word into a negative. 金＝money。 金無い＝ no money.

足.kun_translate: to be enough. Often used in the negative. XXXが足りない!

促.kun_translate: to press or encourage someone to do something. Could be good, as in "Get up and dance! It's a party! Have some fun!" or bad, as in, "Work faster! If there's time to lean, there's time to clean!"

正.kun_translate: correct, in BOTH senses : literally , as in a correct answer. (Implies that there is ONLY ONE correct one). And figuratively: something that is morally correct or just.

定.kun_translate: to ordain or determine (either a rule, a plan, or a time and place for something).

証.kun_translate: evidence, testimony . . .: somewhere in between 証明（しょうめい: proof）　and 証拠　（しょうこ: physical evidence）. You'd typically use 証 when you're talking about evidence of god such as miracles. Or you'd challenge someone "You say you're honest and give to charity, but do you have any evidence of this?" Unlike 証拠、　証　does not have to be physical, it can be verbal.

超.kun_translate: to exceed or go over a certain limit (the cook heated the oven to over 100 degrees, the dude passed 100 years old, the man bet over 40,000 dollars, etc.)

訳.kun_translate: the reason for something  This is not used by itself, only used in expressions, such as "XXX訳だ!!" (so THAT"S the reason!)ｏｒ　”ＸＸＸ訳ではない！”　（It can't effing be!!!）

描.kun_translate: to sketch - a picture, as opposed to the other かく　(書く） which means to write words

打.kun_translate: to pound or strike with a tool (not your hands).

招.kun_translate: invite, summon (a person,  or, more frequently, luck - usually bad, like the English prhase 'tempting fate'))

担.kun_translate: figurative : to carry or assume responsibility or burden.

取.kun_translate: To take a picture. Also, to pick something up off a table or shelf, pick up a small thing like glasses or a plate. Also means to get something (good marks on a test, a prize, etc,).

最.kun_translate: the most (the biggest, the best, the ugliest, etc.)

撮.kun_translate: to take a picture (only used in the context of 撮影, or pro-style photoshoots)

趣.kun_translate: the general vibe of something (a performance, a place) (this is a poetic or literary word)

恥.kun_translate: embarrassed! (or, this being Japan, pretending to be embarrassed!)

誓.kun_translate: a vow. More strong than 約束. The first time you got caught cheating, you'd make a 約束 to not cheat, But the second time you get caught, you have to誓う！！！

訴.kun_translate: to accuse of wrongdoing OR to file a lawsuit.

近.kun_translate: near - both physically, in time, and metaphorically, as in 'Your left boob is so stretched, it's nearly a banana.'

辺.kun_translate: this neighborhood, the vicinity (as opposed to far away or another 'hood)

迫.kun_translate: two meanings:  1) xxx を 迫る :To put pressure on someone to do XXX; to threaten to do xxx to someone.   2)　 に　迫る：  NI is trickier - it has two uses.  2a) YYY に　迫る = approaching YYY. (Near-CD quality, nigh-invulnerable, etc) 2b  ZZZ に　迫る = to threaten Mr. or Mrs. ZZZ.  In other words, を迫る refers to WHAT you're threatening to do, and  に迫る refers to WHO you are threatening.  OK?

込.kun_translate: I put something (usually feelings or emotions or passion, strength) into something (a present, an effort). Or I just put bullets into a fuckin' gun. Seriously, my J-dictionary uses both examples.

進.kun_translate: I advance, proceed, make progress (in writing a novel, moving towards a goal)

述.kun_translate: to relate a story of... Describes the speaker's own actions: ('Please allow me to mention or state something') (usually used in a business or formal setting: opening remarks, proposals, extending a warm welcome, all that glad-handing bullshit)

森.kun_translate: forest : often goes after the name of a specific forest, i.e. "the black forest" would be 黒森

休.kun_translate: a break (a day off=休みの日)

枠.kun_translate: literally, a frame (write you name in this box, etc.). More often used figuratively, a numerical limit: you can use this library card 3 times a month. You can only bring 5 friends with you to the pool. Etc.

刺.kun_translate: to be stuck by (a thumbtack stuck in my shoe, your moms got a whole ham stuck in her throat)

集.kun_translate: I amass a bunch of things

枯.kun_translate: I, personally, desiccate or dry up something

相.kun_translate: partner (only used in 相手, see below!)

案.kun_translate: an idea you just had - or a proposal you're making - to specifically solve a problem.

染.kun_translate: a stain (usually used like this : しみをかける）

和.kun_translate: (used about an angry person or weather) to settle down, relent

秘.kun_translate: to hide, or conceal information, to keep something to one's self.

(BOOBOO: Don't ever start your sentences with 'watashi wa.' That is like the ＃1 noobiest thing ever. If you are going to a school where they teach you to introduce yourself with 'watashi ha', it's ok, but if they want you to start all your sentences that way, quit and find another school.)

移.kun_translate: broad meaning! A transfer or shift - as in, climate change, moving to a new house, transmitting a cold, yawns that are 'catching', fire spreading to the next building, or moving a conversation on to the next subject. These are all 移す！

利.kun_translate: to use (usually a body part) - 口を利く： have a smart mouth. 良く利く鼻: have a great nose, have wonderful smelling-ability. 目が利く: to have a discerning eye (for art/ antiques / etc.)

愁.kun_translate: melancholy- sorrowful - but more subtle than the OTHER うれい　（憂い）。 Regular urei is like a homeless guy that is obviously suffering and you can see why. 愁い is like a elegant woman in a kimono going to a temple and carrying with her a subtle poetic aura of sadness. Older Japanese guys go for this.

末.kun_translate: ｔｈｅ　end of something- end of the month, the end of a story

妹.kun_translate: my younger sister (BOOBOO: if I address YOUR younger sister, it's 'いもうとさん')

米.kun_translate: raw, uncooked rice. The kind you buy in a big 2 kilo bag.

迷.kun_translate: to be paralyzed because you are unable to choose. (i.e. when shopping, or when you are lost and can't decide which street to take)

継.kun_translate: to inherit. Or to get a job because the last person quit. Or to become king, because the old king got mysteriously sick and died.

粘.kun_translate: to be sticky  - usually shortened to  the onomopoetic word ネバネバ!

粋.kun_translate: stylish (present or clothes) but also a considerate or supportive person.(

奥.kun_translate: way in the back： Back of the closet, back of the casket, back of the cave, etc.

臭.kun_translate: BOOBOO: the dictionary says 臭いand 　匂 are both used to mean におい(good smell), but that's bollocks. The truth is much less confusing: 匂い means good smell, and 臭い means bad.

器.kun_translate: bowl or container-but also (rarely) capability (like, KRS ONE has more rappin' capability than Pharrel)

突.kun_translate: to poke or jab, but not necessarily with a sharp object. Could be your finger.

伏.kun_translate: to lay face down - also means, "to keep this a secret, to hide the truth from outsiders."

黙.kun_translate: shut up. Usually said in meirei-kei (the command form) like this: だまれ！

燃.kun_translate: I burn something up, I light something on fire. Intentionally!

勤.kun_translate: to be employed at xxx company (emphasis is on the physical work rather than the role). (used only about a job, and not in reference to a particular project at that job)

嘆.kun_translate: emit a wail of despair or mourning

暮.kun_translate: This doesn't correspond to any English word. Maybe the closest phrase is, "To lead one's life."  Homeless people, retirees, and rich divorcees all 暮らす even though they don't 稼ぐ.  It means "to live in a place" as well as "to do all one's daily junk (eating, sleeping, hanging out)." 暮らす is usually used in sentences  like, "over 30,000 people are living in the city." or "Live on $20 a day," or "She had an easy/hard life."

募.kun_translate: to raise funds, solicit contributions (for a magazine ,etc.), to find workers or soldiers.

幕.kun_translate: literal curtains, as well as metaphorical curtains, as in 'The curtain fell on his career when he got caught humping a loaf.'

恩.kun_translate: gratitude. Unlike the related words 恩恵　（おんけい） and 義理 (ぎり）, 恩 means that you really WANT to do something nice, to give back to the person you're grateful to. Also, unlike 義理、恩 doesn't imply that you owe them a specific favor. Often, 恩 is used like, "Everyone else gave up on me, told me I was a juvenile delinquent, that I'd amount to nothing. That teacher was the only one who believed in me, who kept encouraging me no matter how many times I fucked up. とても恩がある。"

困.kun_translate: to be in trouble. . . .not exactly. It doesn't mean 'punishment' like  'You're in trouble!' means in English. It's not like  your teacher yelling at you.  Often you'd use it like "Oh, shit!", but usually in the past tense, for some reason!  If you're late and can't find your shoes, you'd say  こまった.  (past tense)  If you're lost, then you say  こまった. If you forgot your password for ratemycheneyfanfiction.org, that's . . . actually you're better off, probably. (BOOBOO)

玉.kun_translate: (broad meaning) any ball - a fire-ball, ball bearing, a mathematical sphere, a glass bead. Also it has the nuance of gem, or jewel.

This is also the word used about guys who commit suicide for honor.

悔.kun_translate: this means, "Fuck! I almost had it and then it all went to hell GOD DAMN IT I WAS SO CLOSE!"

侮.kun_translate: to hold in contempt. Usually used about a third party - it's odd to tell someone, "I 侮る you" even if they are an asshole.

仲.kun_translate: :the extent of one's friendship (as in, 仲がいい　or 仲が悪い）

蚊.kun_translate: mosquito (蚊に刺された!  (かにさされた!) =  I got bit by a mosquito!)

Basically meanings ２ and 3 are purely rhetorical - you can delete them from the sentence and the meaning stays the same.

尾.kun_translate: tail (BOOBOO: most people say 尻尾）

甘.kun_translate: a) the wonderful mother/child bond that teaches Japanese kindness and benevolence, b) the mother-child bond that forever stunts the hustle and self-reliance and independence of many Japanese.

某.kun_translate: ：a certain　ｘｘｘ　; it also has the connotation of 'undisclosed', like Dick Cheny's undisclosed location.

謀.kun_translate: to plot a murder! Murder most faoouuullll!!! almost never used.

焼.kun_translate: I roast food, (but sometimes used with other stuff, like 'I burn the flag' or even CD-burning)

境.kun_translate: boundary - can be used with countries OR property lines of 2 pieces of land. Usually used when talking about crossing a boundary, or being within the boundary.

現.kun_translate: to display something, to make something manifest. Second meaning: something becomes clear.

兄.kun_translate: older brother (used about ANYONE's older brother, or even ANY guy that strikes you as being of an 'older brother' age, almost like you could substitute niisan for 'dude')

競.kun_translate: competing to get the best grade, the most sales. 90% overlapping with 競争; same useage and everything. fugeddaboutit.

憤.kun_translate: moral outrage - at corruption, murder, etc. It doesn't have to be expressed by yelling, though. It can be hidden inside.

噴.kun_translate: spew- not vomit, but like lava, fire or high-pressure water. (vomit is 吐く　（はく））

貧.kun_translate: scanty, skimpy, meager.Mostly used about　amounts of  money.

賭.kun_translate: bet/risk (not just money, but also situations like 'She's betting her reputation that her scence theory will disprove Stephen Hawking')

質.kun_translate: quality, as in しつがいい、or しつ が わるい (the quality is good / bad).

損.kun_translate: harm or injury - usually financial harm or financial damage: 機嫌を損なう（きげんをそこなう）

測.kun_translate: to measure, but (unlike the other two はかる　kanji) THIS はかる　 usually used in a medical or scientific context. (blood pressure, air pressure). Also used for area, distance, sound decibels, angle, capacity.

貫.kun_translate: to penetrate all the way through: not just violently. (for example, 'The river runs through the town.') Also to see a project all the way through to the end

責.kun_translate: to blame someone for a problem. To accuse someone of wrongdoing.

積.kun_translate: to pile up things (luggage, cargo, crap) or, to accumulate.

浜.kun_translate: a very casual word for the beach, usually used by people who live on beach-towns.

探.kun_translate: to search for something you want but don't have (a good restaraunt, a store with bargains, sanity).

漂.kun_translate: to drift on the surface of water. A smell drifts through the air . Or (figuratively) an atmosphere or vibe wafts around the place (of mutiny, for example!) a dude gives off a vibe of being a ganster

ただよ＊う

価.kun_translate: value - but not an actual dollar amount (that'd be 値段） . 価 is value as in, ('the value of the antique goes up with time' or 'I'll estimate the value, using my jewler's loupe and tweezers.')

要.kun_translate: to need something　super important - but always written in kana, so I'm giving it a usefullness of zero, even though as a hiragana word it's more like a 3 or 4.

閉.kun_translate: I shut or close (a door, etc.)

夫.kun_translate: kind of formal word for husband

替.kun_translate: I switch from one thing to another thing - usually of a different type: (switch channels / modes / clothes / sides)

挟.kun_translate: crush between two things - as in slam your finger in the car door. (also, to tuck in between 2 things, as in place a bookmark in the book, or wedge the phone between your shoulder and chin) (BOOBOO: does NOT mean pinch, which is つねる）

巣.kun_translate: BOOBOO: this is usually translated as nest, but anywhere an animal lives is a SU. A spider's web, a badger's burrow, are all 巣.

授.kun_translate: to give or grant a prize to someone

採.kun_translate: gather (mushrooms, cherries, honey (if you are a bee)). Also, sometimes, it means to adopt a certain policy or take a certain measure.

久.kun_translate: it's been a long time since I . . .

絡.kun_translate: to get entangled in (a problem, a crime)

略.kun_translate: to omit some information. Usually used like :　りゃくして： "I won't mention in more detail because you already know this part." Or, alternatively:

酸.kun_translate: sour, acidic flavor: lemons, vinegar, pickled plums.

秀.kun_translate: to be excellent /  to surpass xxxx

誘.kun_translate: invite (a friend to dinner) (or sometimes, invite an emotion, as in, a tear-jerker of a movie)
誘.kun_kanji:
(
に　or を
)
さ*そう

透.kun_translate: to ｂｅ　ｓｅｅ－ｔｈｒｏｕｇｈ，(as in, a see-through blouse, or seeing a guy's scalp through his thinning hair) ｕｓｕｓａｌｌｙ　ｐｈｒａｓｅｄ　ｌｉｋｅ　ｔｈｉｓ：　ＸＸＸ　が　透けて見える。

携.kun_translate: ｔｏ　ｂｅ　ｍｉｘｅｄ　ｕｐ　ｉｎ　ｓｏｍｅｔｈｉｎｇ，　ｔｏ　ｐａｒｔｉｃｉｐａｔｅ　ｏｒ　ｃｏｎｃｅｒｎｅｄ　ｗｉｔｈ　ｓｏｍｅｔｈｉｎｇ． ( in the internet business/ a job with computers/ involved in a hijacking incident)

及.kun_translate: influence the outcome or have an effect on. （ｕｓｕａｌｌｙ　ｂａｄ, as in alcohol influencing judgement, or 'what impact does this have on society?'）

扱.kun_translate: Treatment - usually applied to people, but originally used for objects, so it 's a little rude. Usually used like あつかいがいい or あつかいがわるい. Can mean 'treatment of others' but, confusingly, can ALSO mean 'easy or hard for ME to DEAL WITH HIM/HER.' For example, 彼は扱いが難しい does NOT mean 'He treats me difficultly', it means 'He's difficult to deal with.'  (noun)

穏.kun_translate: calm or mild - used about personality AND peaceful places, calm weather, mild ocean. A person who doesn't get mad.

侵.kun_translate: violate something, usually in the sense of rape, but also somtimes: civil rights, copyright, right to privacy, right to free speech, etc. Also used in slander or defemation, for instance if I said the pope only had one nut.

浸.kun_translate: I soak or immerse something, like dipping bread in soup, or a soapy rag.

急.kun_translate: to rush (usually in the present tense, like this : 急いで！（いそいで！））

当.kun_translate: I hit it, I  guess correctly, (telling someone to guess is :当てて御覧！（あててごらん！））

帰.kun_kanji:
(
に or へ
)
かえ＊る

締.kun_translate: to tighten (a knob, guitar strings, a seat-belt, the throat of your 11th victim (each victim you kill in a different way)

躍.kun_translate: to jump repeatedly up and down- as in "jumping jacks."

控.kun_translate: Sometimes means 'to wait,' but often means, 'to repress one's true feelings or refrain from actions you really secretly want to do. ' Pretty much the same as 抑える、 but there are two important distinctions: 抑える is something you do because society forces you to, but 控える is something you do because YOU want to. Also 控える is usually used about repressing or refraining from doing ACTIONS, while 抑える usually referrs to only repressing feelings.

巧.kun_translate: schmoov. Schmooov! A clever ad slogan, slick flattery, adroit political manipulation, etc.

与.kun_translate: to give, grant, bestow (give a kid an allowance / give someone a chance / a degree in Doctorology / an award / food to a pet)

写.kun_translate: I copy something using the xerox machine / I take a picture

極.kun_translate: extremely. good OR bad. Usually used like: ｘｘｘ極める; extremely good　at XXX. Or, the tyrant was extremely cruel.

号.kun_translate: a SUFFIX which you put after a numbered item （apartment number, account number, etc.) Like, if you live in room 204, you'd say に　ゼロ　よん　号。

考.kun_translate: to think (about a problem or your options or the meaning of some shit)

代.kun_translate: something is exchanged or one person succeeds another. A robot replaces a human, (who is made into Soylent Green)

貸.kun_translate: lend, or rent, which is kind of fucked up that they use the same word for a generous act and a usorious one.

惑.kun_translate: get bewildered (by your own ignorance, accidentally) or led astray (by someone else, deliberately)

我.kun_translate: us (kind of formal, an 'older guy' word) (gives the impression that you're making a speech)

賊.kun_translate: a bandit or rebel- not like a lone mugger, but a bunch of dudes hiding in the countryside outside of government control, all Robin Hood style

戦.kun_translate: fight physically - either with fists or armies. (sometimes used figuratively - fight crime!) But in any case, 戦う usually refers to an ongoing struggle rather than a single barroom punch-up.

駆.kun_translate: gallop (animals), or to rush/exert a lot of effort (humans)

拒.kun_translate: absolute refusal - it can be physical as well as verbal. For example, if someone refuses to shake your hand, that's 拒む。

堅.kun_translate: unlike the other 2 かたいs, this one is FIGURATIVE : hard as in a steadfast, Sam Gamgee-ass pal. certain, reliable, solid. But 堅い also has a bad meaning: too stuffy, formal, rigid and bound by tradition

臨.kun_translate: the dictionary says it means "to face", like "You 'll face sanctions if you keep trying to build atomic weapons." , But usually it has the nuance of "Stand strong and resolute even in the face of something scary". Like, "He must face terrorism without flinching."

喚.kun_translate: (almost always hiragana) - yell in an angry way, but you're still using words.

換.kun_translate: exchange (yen for euros) change (diapers / a broken heel on your pumps) Unlike the other かえる　(替える）、 換える means you are exchanging something for a similar or identical thing

欠.kun_translate: to lack an abstract thing (experience / confidence / creativity / trust) （BOOBOO: if you want to say you don't have enough of a physical thing (for instance, money!) you'd say 足りない (たりない）instead.)

歌.kun_translate: song (BOOBOO: 歌 is generally used only for songs with lyrics. Instrumentals are きょく　（曲）

敗.kun_kanji:
(
で or に
)
やぶ＊れる

故.kun_kanji:
ゆえ

)

激.kun_translate: severe, violent, intense　Has the nuance of something that is aggressive and over-full of energy: weather, emotions, or even a place that is crazy packed and busy can be hageshii.

攻.kun_translate: attack - specifically, something which has been planned in advance. Not a bar-room brawl. You could use it about an army attack, but also about a fencer who deliberately chooses a certain attack-style to defeat her opponent.

摘.kun_translate: literally, to prune - the  gardener prunes the bushes.   Figuratively, to nip in the bud.  It's often used in the phrase 才能を摘む (sainou wo tsumu,to stunt the emotional growth of your kids).(BOOBOO: plucking a single flower is ぬく, not つむ）

己.kun_translate: myself- a very LITERARY way of saying 私

改.kun_translate: change PLUS improvement. Usually used with behavior - meaning to turn over a new leaf, to quit self-destructive or bad behavior. Also has a totally unrelated meaning: When a customs official or police asks to see your ID card, that's also 改める for some reason.

配.kun_translate: pass out by hand: flyers or whatever

救.kun_translate: to rescue　(really dramatic - only use this regarding bankruptcy or death).

励.kun_translate: to cheer up or encourage someone

備.kun_translate: set some shit aside for an emergency. (for instance, by saving money for a rainy day, or by stocking the basement with canned food for when the Apocalypse comes).

産.kun_translate: to give birth (human or animal) .This is more of a medical or agricultural word. Normally we use the OTHER うむ　（生む） for everyday childbirth.

原.kun_translate: a high plain. (not useful, unless you are a High Plains Drifter, and concoct a Black and Tan in your brandy Snifter)

源.kun_translate: a spring like where water comes out of the ground

坂.kun_translate: a slope of a hill (BOOBOO: not the hill itself. Hills are the similar-sounding おか！）

仮.kun_translate: suppose, as in "Suppose, for the sake of argument, that you were a doctor".

誠.kun_translate: faithfulness, fidelity　to your boss or superior person.

越.kun_translate: I go beyond (a physical thing)  - I pass or crosss something (a lake, a city, etc)

蔵.kun_translate: an obsolete word for a building where you  store food on farm - a silo or barn.

幻.kun_translate: a phantom, an illusion　－ like 幻覚 but more broad - it can be sounds, tastes, etc.

気.kun_translate: basically, 'mood', but there are over 3,000 expressions that use it. KI can be put in, become exhausted ,become lost, change, be pulled, be big, small, changing. KI gets followed, met, used, lightened, lengthened, shortened, rotated, cut. KI can be strong, weak, floating, heavy. . .. but you never say, "how's your ki doing ?" or "I've got great ki today!"  - You have to use it as part of an expression.

獣.kun_translate: a beast - used about literal animals - not neccesairly the hugest or scariest, but animals that are both violent AND unclean, like the hyena. Also used about people who behave like those animals.

筒.kun_translate: usually defined as pipe but more accurately, it means cylinder.  Chimney, exhaust pipe, drainage pipe, gun barrel, canister, are all 筒. （BOOBOO: unlike the related kanji 管　(tube), which can bend, 筒 is always straight).

伺.kun_translate: formal visit　(only used by the lower person who is visiting the upper person)  Also formal way of saying "ask" (ditto: lower to upper)

表.kun_translate: FRONT surface- used only about things that have a front-and-back. (opposite: 裏　うら） . Usually used about 2-dimensional things (paper, walls) but can also be used with the ol' tatemae/honne.

衣.kun_translate: garment in the abstract sense - the garment district, a clothes closet, etc.

裁.kun_translate: to judge or put someone on trial

裏.kun_translate: sorry to disappoint, it don't mean backside like 'booty,' but backside like,    1) the back side of a building, behind something where few people go.  2) the 'dark side' - illegal or hidden side of something.

哀.kun_translate: you poor bastard! God help you. Utterly fucked, pathetic, but you honestly feel bad for them, rather than just looking down on them.

衰.kun_translate: a decline in life-energy. (used only about living things) Usually brought about by sickness, aging, or stress.

退.kun_translate: withdraw (from competition, troops withdraw from the Gaza strip, sometimes also means retire).
