しりぞ*く

眼.kun_translate: eye　(BOOBOO: unless you're reading a medical textbook, most people use the other め：目）

恨.kun_translate: to hold a long-term, soul-eating, ulcer-making grudge- against the bitch who stole your boyfriend, etc.

限.kun_kanji:
(
を　or に
)
かぎ＊る

障.kun_translate: Hinder - but could also be translated as 'take a toll on', as in, "The problems at work hindered his sleep." 'The excessive drinking took a toll on her health.'

防.kun_translate: To hinder in the sense of 'guard against': anti-crime cameras, anti-theft devices, and such all use this kanji. 防ぐ is more 'positive' than words like 触る or 阻む which usually mean 'hinder something you're trying to do.'

部.kun_translate: SUFFIX meaning "the XXX" club (baseball, origami, etc.)

装.kun_translate: to pretend or feign. (like '振る' - except that 振るmeans you're fooling yourself, while 装う means you're trying to fool others.)

寝.kun_translate: lie down, go to bed (BOOBOO： it does NOT mean 'sleep,' which is 眠る!)

背.kun_translate: height. (NUBI) You gotta say like 背が高い! or 背が低い!

制.kun_translate: to supress or control (the serfs, your impulses, etc.)

造.kun_translate: to mass-produce something in a factory. (although one-of-a-kind things like a giant rocket ship are also 造る)

酷.kun_translate: terrible! Not like a terrible movie, but like going on a date and your date vomits shrimp all over your dad. Because your date IS your dad.

面.kun_translate: 2 meanings  1) ENTIRE surface of a 3-dimensional object, as opposed to 表, which is the front surface of a 2-D object (deeeeyammn!!),  2) the head or face - usually used in the context of expressions like 'meet face to face' or 'dare you to say it to my face!'. In other words, you wouldn't tell a drunk model, 'Hey there, nice 面！’

優.kun_kanji:
(
に or が
)
ずぐ＊れる

縮.kun_translate: contract (lips pucker, the sphincter contracts, the circle closes in around the hunted man)

砂.kun_translate: grain - (BOOBOO: not grain of rice or wheat (living things' grains are 粒（つぶ））--- use 砂　about  grains of sand or sugar；mineral things.)

砕.kun_translate: I pulverize something. Construction workers smash the sidewalk concrete to dust. The mill turns wheat into flour.  Can also mean 'To foil your plans.' Unlike the related term 割る(わる)、 砕く tends to take a certain amount of time and repeated smashings.

礎.kun_translate: foundation (easy to remember since the first part looks AND SOUNDS like 石　（いし）

帯.kun_translate: belt, (BOOBOO: this only refers to a traditional obi worn with kimono. Not like a modern belt, which is ベルト!)

滞.kun_translate: be overdue, left undone, backed-up (piles of unpaid bills teeter on the edge of your desk)

催.kun_translate: host a small event - an art opening, house party, etc.

鳴.kun_translate: animal's sound. Not just loud angry animals either. Baby birds also naku.

喜.kun_translate: to make someone become glad or  happy - generally said about people other than yourself.
喜.kun_kanji:
(
が or に or で
)
よろこ＊ぶ

嬉.kun_translate: to be really happy - but it also has a connotation of gratitude. You get 嬉しい when you get a present from someone, but not when the sun comes up and it's a rad-weather day. (BOOBOO: unlike "よろこぶ," you usually use 'ureshii' about yourself.)

願.kun_translate: a fairly serious request: お願いがあります（ I have a favor to ask you). その願いを叶える (I'll grant your wish.) Can you buy me a car! Can you loan me money? Can you bail me out of jail?

頂.kun_translate: the summit of a mountain. A sort of literary or formal word.

額.kun_translate: forehead (BOOBOO: most people just say おでこ instead  - different word, and not even written in kanji. So you can go ahead and ignore ひたい)

顧.kun_translate: to look back  . Can be used literally OR figuratively, both with a good meaning (nostalgia, reminisince) and bad (guilty, reflecting on past misdeeds) .Also, to consider the consequences of something you're about to do (in which case, it's used in the negative：he acted without thinking!).

傾.kun_translate: I tilt or tip something in a certain direction.

川.kun_translate: river. Simple, isn't it? Well, beware: if it's used in the name of a specific river, half the time it's pronounced SEN instead!

州.kun_translate: Usually this is only used with foreign countries, like 'California州' or 'Tennessee 州. '   Japan doesn't have states, but sometimes you'll see a place-name such as 九州 (kyushuu).

荒.kun_translate: wild or rough - (BOOBOO : not like 'girls gone wild' but like bums or abandoned houses that go wild and have dirt and weeds growing out of them)

慌.translate: be in a rush / freaked out
慌.kun_translate: to be in a rush (or busy) to the point where you freak out; to panic

道.kun_translate: smaller street (BOOBOO: bigger streets are 通り (どうり))

説.kun_translate: to explain, preach, or hold forth on an important subject (BOOBOO: usually we just say . . .説明 (setsumei suru))

詳.kun_translate: an expert- not always a professional in the field, but  someone who has a detailed knowledge of shit.

洋.kun_translate: 'Western style XXX' (xxx is always pronounced onyomi)

遅.kun_translate: to be slow moving / to be late

養.kun_translate: to foster, raise, breed, cultivate. usually about animals. Or orphans. (seriously!)

様.kun_translate: SUFFIX which goes after someone's name to be polite.

添.kun_translate: A formal word for "to append" or - better yet - "to be included" . To go along with, to accompany (not used with people - in that case you'd say 伴う（ともなう））　添える is more like, the CDR comes with the textbook. Or the applesauce comes with the pork chops.

呑.kun_translate: chug. Drink in one gulp, (emphasis on swallowing) (use this about medicine, chugging booze, or dudes reaching a desert oasis). Also, figuratively, to accept an onerous demand.

送.kun_translate: send (letter) or transmit (radio or tv program)

咲.kun_translate: bloom (you'd think that this would also be the same kanji as SAKURA (the cherry blossoms). You'd be wrong. Sakura is 桜。)

巻.kun_translate: roll up (a scroll), wind up (fishing line)

弟.kun_translate: someone's younger brother (say if you're talking to your friend's younger brother)

沸.kun_translate: to be boiling. Usually used with お湯, (hot water) as in, お湯が沸く ('The water's boiling!')

費.kun_translate: to spend, to consume, to waste. Can also be used of time(literally, 'consume time' ), in the context of work. 時間を費やす: which translates to : it was time well spent / it was time wasted.

強.kun_translate: compel, or force someone to do something

跡.kun_translate: a trace left behind, a vestige

恋.kun_translate: usually translated as love, but lust is closer!

張.kun_translate: to physically make something longer. stretch a rubber-band、 stretch a canvas on a paint frame, pitch a tent. Also to extend one's influence.

険.kun_translate: a steep hill, or a very grim situation (but mostly a steep hill).

金.kun_translate: スクリーラ!!! キャッシュ ルールス エブリシング アラウンド ミー!

全.kun_translate: Entirely, all of it. This is one of the most common Japanese words, but hey -- it's usually written in hiragana, so I'm not sure you need to learn this?

企.kun_translate: to scheme, to be up to something. to be hatching a nefarious plan.

飾.kun_translate: to decorate your room/ lunchbox / fingernails

飯.kun_translate: literally, cooked rice. But usually used to mean, 'a meal.'

余.kun_translate: the excess, surplus (excess labor drives down wages) (surplus food rots on docks)
余.kun_kanji:
(
に or が
)
あま＊る

塗.kun_translate: to paint, or to smear.Like foundation makeup. Or mud.

合.kun_translate: to suit. The burlap sack suits your mama's hippo behind.

拾.kun_translate: pick up off the ground, pick up big thing like a box.

命.kun_translate: life. As in, 'He had a long life.' or 'Your money or your life!' or 'Cling to life by a thread.'

冷.kun_translate: cold- both literally and figuratively. Also, bad puns are つめたい.

尽.kun_translate: to do everything in one's power , to exhaust every option trying to do XXX.

終.kun_translate: "the end" - usually written at the end of old movies. Also said out loud by someone who wants to declare victory and change the subject.

次.kun_translate: next　(for example, 次の日 means the next day)

姿.kun_translate: a figure, a shape. As in, ‘I’ve got a bad figure ’ or ‘She saw a shadowy figure emerge from the darkness’

春.kun_translate: spring, or sexy (think of the English expression 'spring fever' if you don't see the connection)

実.kun_translate: usually used like this：'実は xxx,' which is like saying 'The truth is...', as in, 'The truth is ,I used to be a dude named Carlos.'

偏.kun_translate: Figuratively, to be biased. Literally, to have an assymetrical distribution of objects. For example, "There are crows in every prefecture, but there is a much higher distribution of them in Aichi prefecture." Or,aesthetically speaking, "I put all the chairs on the left side of the room to make it かたよる."
偏.kun_kanji:
(
が　or に or は
)
かたよ＊る

討.kun_translate: revenge-attack- the literal meaning is "get some motherfucking payback for the death of my daimyo". almost never used, but it's wild that they have a word for that specific kind of attack.

尋.kun_translate: ask- basically it's the same as 聞く, but you'd be more likely to use 尋ねる when asking a clerk something at a store. They're both really casual, but 尋ねる is a bit more businesslike.

導.kun_translate: to lead or guide - in the sense of MORAL guidance, reforming a juvenile delinquent, to lead by example, etc.

闘.kun_translate: fight - (only used figuratively) - struggle against temptation, war on poverty, the, uh, the uh, hold on, the effin'  war on drugs, struggle against prejudice, etc.

時.kun_translate: time, as in 'That time your mom shaved her beard.'

持.kun_translate: to hold, but also to own, and often, to bring. As in 'Buy some nachos and bring them to the party.'

侍.kun_translate: samurai, bitch!!!　（BOOBOO: most of the time, Japanese don't say samurai, they'll say 武士　（ぶし） instead. The only time actual Japanese say "samurai" is when they're referring to something very concrete things like "samurai haircut" or "Samurai TV drama."）

等.kun_translate: equivalent : usually in the mathematical sense, but can also be used figuratively, "He's as good as dead!" "Your lies are tantamount to treason, and I'll see you hanged!!" This is closer to the non-judgemental 同じ than it is to the moralistic 公平　（fair)

父.kun_translate: father,(which is weird, considering that chichi also means 'tits,' which is basically what the 'mother' kanji depicts. So why isn't 'mama' called chichi?)

交.kun_kanji:
(
が or に
)
まじ＊わる

効.kun_translate: xxx is effective, most often said about medicine or drugs.

縛.kun_translate: To bind something - to tie a string AROUND something - to shackle a prisoner, to tie up a masochist, to put one's hair in a pony tail (BOOBOO: to tie a knot is 結ぶ　（むすぶ））.

薄.kun_translate: weak or thin flavor. A cup of coffee with one bean.

敷.kun_translate: to spread out (a tarpaulin), to lay out (railroad tracks)

満.kun_translate: to fill up, either literally or metaphorically (e.g. to satisfy or fulfill)

屈.translate: yield, get out of the way

揺.kun_translate: I shake or shock something : I make something sway

喋.kun_kanji:
(
を or と
)
しゃべ＊る

離.kun_translate: to leave someone, to be distant (both physically and emotionally)

矢.kun_translate: arrow  - never used by itself  (see below!)

知.kun_translate: to know something or someone. (BOOBOO: as opposed to 分かります, which means 'Oh shit! now I get it!' or 'I just realized / comprehended something!')  Typical example: 'Do you know the band Rotting Christ?' (ロッチング・キリストというバンドを知ってる？）

失.kun_translate: to miss out on. Like you were watching tv too much and missed out on a pool party in your own backyard.

観.kun_translate: to watch something, deliberately and for a long time, In other words, to be a spectator at something (only used in the phrase 観にいく . And you only used 観に行く about concerts, broadway plays, and art exhibitions). Basically this is 聴く for your eyes.

陣.kun_translate: xxx's camp or base, usually but not always military

輪.kun_translate: can mean ring, like rings of saturn, or loop, like cable which is stored in a loop, or circle, like folk-dances where everyone forms a circle. But 輪 is never an actual ring like you wear on your finger.

載.kun_translate: to include something in the final version, include in the published report. Confusingly, 載せる can also can mean 'put on top of something' : 'put the skis on vehicle' or 'put something on top of the cabinet'
載.kun_kanji:
(
を or に
)
の＊せる

連.kun_translate: bring someone with you to the zoo, the party, etc.　(99% used like this: ｘｘｘを連れて行く (つれていく））

運.kun_translate: to transport - unlike はいたつ(配達）, 運ぶ is NOT related to business or money. If you help your friend move his fridge to his new place, that's 運ぶ. If you pick up your suitcase and take it to the airport, that's 運ぶ。

華.onyomi: KA - same as the OTHER flower kanji
華.kun_translate: in theory, it means flower, but in practice no one ever uses it that way. If you use it twice in a row: 華々しい、(はなばなしい),　it means gorgeous or flamboyant. . . so you can still see the roots of the flower (heh)..

腫.kun_translate: swell up ー not like a boner, like you got stung by a bee.

軽.kun_translate: lightweight, but also mild or carefree.

経.kun_translate: usually used in the phrase : 時間が経つ・ time passes. Usually a long time. Like, "After three days, the letter arrived."

怪.kun_translate: suspicious. Not like "I'm suspicious of him," but like "He's acting shady."

抜.kun_translate: I pluck or extract something - pluck a carrot out the ground, pluck out a gray hair, The mouse plucks the thorn out of the lion's paw.If you bleach the color out of cloth or hair, you're 色を抜く. plucking the color out!

雄.kun_translate: PREFIX meaning 'male XXX' as in 'male cat' or 'male hippo.' BOOBOO: You don't say 'osuhito' though.

希.kun_translate: very similar to めずらしい(unusual), but more formal/newspapery. Also has the connotation of rare-because-it's-valuable (endangered species, a rare talent, etc.) If you see a dog-turd shaped like Lyle Lovett, that's 珍しい , not まれ。

堕.kun_translate: fall into moral ruin (become a junkie, get all caught up in a cult or gambling debts, etc.)

賄.kun_translate: to cover the costs of some expenditure. To provide capital for a task

差.kun_translate: point at (usually used about light - flashlights or stage lights, spotlights pointing at someone).　Apparently it also means to wear a sword, or to set people against each other. WTF this kanji makes no sense. Anyway the important thing is, if you want to say 'point with your finger,' you have to use one of the OTHER さすs (指す）)
差.kun_kanji:
(
を or 　が
)
さ＊す

暖.kun_translate: warm place or weather - use this one when you come in from the cold.  Often shortened to あったかい！

彩.kun_translate: to color something in; to show something off- always figuratively: 'The setting sun painted the sky orange' 'The festival showcases the unique atmosphere of the town.'

参.kun_translate: When you say まいた！！ it means, to say uncle, or　!No mas! (Confusingly, it can also mean 'I'm fed up!' 'Fuck this, I'm outta here.')  However, there's another meaning: to visit an important place.　（luckily, this JERK meaning is very formal and almost never used anymore)     What is really fucked up is, usually when a word has 2 meanings, you can tell which meaning it is by the particle. But with MAIRU, both meanings use NI.
参.kun_kanji:
(
が or に
)
まい＊る

惨.kun_translate: pathetic. Unlike the related term 哀れ(あわれ),　惨め is a pretty un-sympathetic word you use for some poor schmuck who is in a wretched state but, you know, you couldn’t imagine them ever being happy anyway.

膨.kun_translate: swelling - not only of body parts, but of ANYTHING: sails swell in the wind, the universe expands. Often used to describe debt: 借金が膨らむ。

珍.kun_translate: rare! Unusual. but not necessarily valuable.

磨.kun_translate: brush :(almost always used with teeth: 歯を磨く　（は　を　みがく)

腐.kun_translate: to rot、to go bad (like food left out too long) 、

店.kun_translate: a shop, speaking generally. "I got to go open the shop now." (The speaker can use this no matter what kind of shop it is).

広.kun_translate: wide, spacious (can be used about interiors but also outside spaces)

席.kun_translate: A public seat - on the bus, or in a theater:Is that seat free? This restaurant seats ２8 people. and so on.

度.kun_translate: Every time XXX happens, YYY happens.

渡.kun_translate: to pass an object to someone (like, 'Pass the peas')

鬼.kun_translate: demon. (the red guys with kabuki wigs and horns)

醜.kun_translate: the type of stick that hit your Moms way back when.

塊.kun_translate: lit:clump, cluster. Also used figuratively to describe someone's personality : a greedy guy is 欲の塊ー'a clump of greed.'

卑.kun_translate: foul, trifling,low, despicable - not used trivially. Used about child molesters and such.. Often used like this: 'XXXに いやしい',where XXX is the thing he's a dick about.

低.kun_translate: low (temperature, blood pressure,low voice, low hill)

眠.kun_translate: sleepy from being up all day (BOOBOO: not to be confused with being tired from work or exercise, which is 疲れる)

豊.kun_translate: abundant - like a rainforest abundant in life or a country's abundant natural resources. You can also use it for a person - he has a lot of education or a wealth of wisdom. (but not used for actual dollars - in that case you'd use 裕福 (yuufuku)。）

遭.translate: chance meeting、 usually with something bad
遭.kun_translate: just like the other 'au' (合う) but only used with sudden and random disasters, such as a car accident, a mugging, etc.

濃.kun_translate: thick or dense, like a dense fog or really strong coffee.

振.kun_translate: to brandish or wave something around

登.kun_translate: climbー only used with mountains, cliffs and ladders.

際.kun_translate: SUFFIX attatched to a place or thing , meaning 'close to' or 'on the border or edge of' something- usually used with locations: 'I'm standing on the edge of the ocean, where it meets the shore.' It is pronounced GIWA.

察.kun_translate: CULTURAL CODE WORD. To infer the feelings of other people (usually in the sense of being a good host or sentitive friend) (as opposed to 気が利く , which refers to actually physically doing something for that person, based on what you さっするed!).

擦.kun_translate: to rub, to wear out, to lose one's naivety.

廃.kun_translate: to become obsolete or go out of fashion

形.kun_translate: form. Literally the shape of something (unlike the other かた　（型）、you can use 形 regardless of if that thing is unique or very conventional).

研.kun_translate: to grind or hone - usually a knife. But sometimes you can hone a skill, just like in English.

型.kun_translate: 2 meanings: model and type.   Model, as in clay/plaster mold, or cookie-cutter stamp, or (figuratively) as in a social convention or conformity. ('this book is too cliche, it just follows all the rules of the style!').   Type as in blood type, or "new type" (i.e. this year's model of crime-fighting robot).

惚.kun_translate: to fall in love with　－ unlike 愛 (ai)  or 恋愛 (renai), 惚れる is more often used to describe a one-sided affection - first you 惚れる and if you're lucky the other person likes you back, and THEN you get your 恋愛。 If you know what I mean.

易.kun_translate: easy,simple to do. (BOOBOO: don't mix it up with the other 'yasashii' (優し), which means kindhearted)

揚.kun_translate: This is one of the more weird words. . . You don't use this for 'raise your hand' or 'raise a barbell over your head.' You use this for hoisting a flag, deep-frying tempura, and honestly that's about it. How's that for random?

傷.kun_translate: damage to one's body. Broken bones and such (visible or not).

場.kun_translate: SUFFIX! xxx場 means 'the place where　we do XXX' (i.e. graveyard is 'grave-場, slaughter house is 'slaughter 場' and so on) Unlike the related kanji 所,　場 emphasizes the activity rather than the location.

免.kun_translate: to get out of (your punishment, because you had a good excuse), get out of paying a fine (because you are related to the Chief of Police).　Basically, it means you got an exemption.

逸.kun_translate: is this always KANA? Yes. You don't need the kanji for this. Oh, by the way, it means 'To deviate, diverge, go wide of the mark.'

絶.kun_translate: to sever - usually figurative: to cut off all relations with (your ex) , or to totally quit doing (alcohol).

像.kun_translate: a statue (BOOBOO: in practice, it’s much more common to use オブジェ, from the French word 'objet')

縁.kun_translate: rim or edge of table, cup, picture frame (emphasis is that it's not a point on the edge, it's the ENTIRE edge)

稼.kun_translate: to earn me a living at xxx. "She likes to DJ but she can't make a living at it." 　（How much money do you make? = どのぐらい稼ぐ？）

遂.kun_translate: accomplish; carry out  (usually used with work (Boss, I can't accomplish this task without more resources!) or with a computer process (working. . . 97% complete)

行.kun_kanji:
(
へ or に
)
い＊く

後.kun_translate: after. Usually used like this: XXXの＊あと, or simply あとで！

得.kun_translate: to obtain (usually used with non-physical things: to obtain permission, or the right to do something, sentitive information, a patron, a prize or promotion )

微.kun_translate: ：slight, faint ( a faint odor of maternal musk is enough to repel most rottweilers)

育.kun_translate: to bring up or to raise a child/underling

徹.kun_translate: be devoted to a project, do nothing else, heart-and-soul. Also means, to stay up all night because you're so focused on your project Star-16

流.kun_translate: various meanings. . . .to make something flow - to flush a toilet. - Also means, a DJ plays music. Which is pretty rad.

陰.kun_translate: shadow, both literally , and more likely, metaphorically. If someone is operating shady deals from the shadows, you use this kanji.

銃.kun_translate: any type of fire-arm. "I got myself and uzi and my brother a nine." - KRS ONE

至.kun_translate: to get to, to arrive. To extend to. Until the very top/bottom/end. (至るところ= everywhere, wall-to-wall) (xxx至るまで= all the way to xxx, even to the extent of xxx)

致.kun_translate: most dictionaries/websites describe this as 'to bring about' which is kind of ambiguous and makes it more confusing than it is.  It's better to think of いたす　as THE POLITE FORMAL VERSION OF する.  (usually KANA, so I'm only givin' it one star! *)

去.kun_translate: to leave (as in leave while others stay). also to be xxx miles away from a particular place.

怯.kun_translate: To be intimidated. Sometimes it is used the same way as more popular cousin 怖がる　（こわがる）: to be scared. But often it connotes a very specific form of fear : to be cowed, scared into submission - usually used with things like political intimidation or domestic violence. To be scared into complying or obeying.

屋.kun_translate: a store which only sells xxx (本屋= bookstore, パン屋= bread store, etc.)

握.kun_translate: to grasp - Usually grab is just 持って　（もって）. 握る is more specific: grabbing and squeezing! (someone's hand, or a baseball bat, or some free weights).

留.kun_translate: Here's the DUPE part: DICTIONARIES say 　留まる, along with 止まる, both mean 'to stop something.' Luckily 留まる is never used, so you don't have to worry about confusing it with 止まる.

伝.kun_translate: I tell someone (use this one for, "Tell her I said hello!")

掛.kun_translate: I hang something using a hook or pin. Also, to sprinkle something on something else (pepper, salt, etc.) Also means to drape over : drape a blanket over a sleeping child or put a tablecloth on the um uh table. Also means to turn on something electric, although how this is different from 使う is unclear!

勢.kun_translate: most dictionaries/books/apps define this as POWER but it's more like momentum, (a power which is in motion). The power to influence something - like "The car had a lot of 勢い so it was hard to stop the car before we hit the cat." or "Because of the whiskey's 勢い, I could do a table dance in the White House."    Also means to gain steam or lose steam - said of political momentum or the momentum of a trend or ideology.

熱.kun_translate: a hot thing. Also can be used figuratively for hot emotions.

肌.kun_translate: refers to the skin of a person - not to leather or animal skin (BOOBOO)

風.onyomi: FUU - but half the time just FU.

飢.kun_translate: to starve (xxxにうえてる =  metaphorically hungry for xxx (knowledge or power ,etc.))

拠.translate: evidence which is the basis for a judgment

恐.kun_translate: to dread or really fear something.Basically the same as 怖がる  but a little more formal.

役.kun_translate: a role. Use this about actors (役を演ずる： play a role!) Also used about businessmen who hold a certain post of position. That's right: post or position, not just role.

設.kun_translate: to establish (a committee to look into the matter)（a political party), to found (a hospital or think tank) , provide (money) , or throw (a party for a valuable customer) . More broad and casual than the related term 設定（せってい）

股.kun_translate: crotch (BOOBOO: usually  people say またのとこと)

真.kun_translate: PREFIX meaning,absolutely totally entirely XXX. usually used with colors.(まっかい、　まっしろい, etc). The words using this prefix always use the KUNyomi.

慎.kun_translate: to be cool-headed, prudent, or discreet when it comes to something potentially disruptive. Could also be translated as 'refrain', like, 'refrain from smoking or talking loudly.' 'Don't say fuck. Watch your lanauge when you talk to nuns.'

懸.kun_translate: literally, to hang or suspend something.   But since usually Japanese use the 掛 kanji to mean hang, 懸 is more often used figuratively: meaning, to gamble or stake something. One's life, one's heart, one's money, etc.

直.kun_translate: to fix / reform / correct a problem ( a broken chair, an inneficient beuraracrarcy, a poorly spelled word). Doesn't mean the thing was  totally fucked up. Sometimes 直す just means do some minor alterations or revisions to make some shit perfect. Also means redo, as in かけ直して (phone me back).

置.kun_translate: to put something down (put a pack of anchovies down on the bear's carcass) (that's not a mnemonic, BTW. That's just what I usually put down and where I usually put it).

別.kun_translate: to separate, like 'break up with', or like when you separate wheat from the chaff.

列.kun_translate: a line of people or things which have been lined up. その列は、何ですか? means, 'What is this line for?' (it's for tickets to see ＱUEEN；THE MUSICAL)

裂.kun_translate: I pick apart something strand by strand - string cheese, cloth, etc. (why they have a word specifically for this is beyond me) . Also, to break people apart, like Romeo and Juliet.

支.kun_translate: support - usually literal: a crutch supports a heavy tree limb or an injured person.

皮.kun_translate: skin, (human or animal -  also skin of an apple, or even the crust of bread!) (BOOBOO: don't use this for fur-covered skin, which is  毛皮）

技.kun_translate: a style or technique (usually used about martial arts, skateboard moves, or rappers, moreso than artisans or factory manufacturing)

序.kun_translate: the first part - also means the order. as in, 序に xxx　（in　order of XXX)

預.kun_translate: to deposit (money in a bank) to leave (your backpack with the paranoid cashier of the CD store)
預.kun_kanji:
(
を　・　に
)
あず*ける

柔.kun_translate: flexible, mild, gentle. In pornos, when someone grabs a handful of boobie and yells 'やわらかい!!' they're using this kanji, not 軟。Also you can use 柔らかい for an object which bends like a novelty 'krazy straw', or if you tap it with your finger, the finger leaves a little dent (dead body).

務.kun_translate: to work in the capacity of XXX, to play the role of XXX (not used with actual actors, though)
務.kun_kanji:
(
に or xxxを
)
つと＊める

疎.kun_translate: emotionally distant from, or: to not know a lot about

頼.kun_translate: to ask someone to do something for you. You can use this when ordering food at a restaraunt, but also when asking a favor from a friend. たのむ has the nuance that the person being asked can refuse.

整.kun_translate: to arrange or prepare - usually used with "prepare a hairstyle", or "clean up a sentence on a re-write of a paper", and not used anywhere else. Sometimes books will refer to someone who is pretty as having a 整った顔 (totono-ta kao) (literally: a well-arranged face!)

踊.kun_translate: to dance (BOOBOO: in conversation people are more likely to say ダンス）

柄.kun_translate: pattern - both representational (i.e. flower wallpaper) and abstract (the pattern of wood-grain).

痛.kun_translate: OW!!!!  To say in a slang way：  いってえ!  Or if you're an old man：  てってってってって!  . . .but those last two aren't ever written using the kanji.

疲.kun_translate: be tired from hard work - (BOOBOO:not to be confused with 眠い( ねむい), which means tired because you're up past your bedtime.)
疲.kun_kanji:
(
が　or　に
)
つか*れる

癒.kun_translate: healing (noun) (emphasis on making the pain go away: the healing effect of music, or the healing power of the Ganges)

諭.kun_translate: NOT VERY USEFUL. Means to gently advise or guide someone. Not a scolding, but it has the connotation of parent-to-child.
諭.kun_kanji:
(
と　・　に
)
さと*す

癖.kun_translate: bad habit. But not that bad. Gambling or hoe-hopping is like a "akushumi". 癖 is just like biting your nails or saying "like" a lot, although it is usually more unique and distinctive.

避.kun_translate: dodge (a bullet, a kick) (can be used figuratively; avoid the consequences, escape punishment)

申.kun_translate: When you're talking to a superior person, you use 申す instead of 言う to describe your own speech. (Instead of saying, 'My name is Ruttiger', you'd say 'Ruttigerともうします！’）

捜.kun_translate: search for something you lost (carkeys, sanity) or cops searching for a criminal.

伸.kun_translate: to intentionally stretch , to extend.  Unlike the OTHER のばす　（延ばす）、伸ばす is more used with things: stretch your back, extend a collapsible umbrella/telescope/ admantium claw.

届.kun_translate: to give your paperwork to the bureauacrats, to give an official report.

隅.kun_translate: corner of a room (BOOBOO: corner of an object - a table, a sheet of paper, etc, is 角　（かど））

雷.kun_translate: lightning and thunder (in Japanese, the same word applies to both, which kind of makes sense)

漏.kun_translate: to leak, to spill. Again, both literally and figuratively (I spilled the beans!)

湿.kun_translate: to moisten or dampen - like when you lick your fingers to turn the page.

竜.kun_translate: In theory, the kunyomi of dragon is TATSU - but oddly it's never used ABOUT DRAGONS THEMSELVES. For example, if you see a dragon, you have to use the ON yomi - 'Hey! It's a ryuu!' However - CONFUSINGLY - some jukugo - such as 'seahorse' and 'tornado' use this kunyomi (TATSU). . . .It's basically the reverse of how kun and on are usually used.

俺.kun_translate: me (only used by guys or scandalous blue-collar grandmas (or anyone imitating those groups)

耐.kun_translate: withstand something physical - Fire resistant, or water-resistant. People, too: if you try to be a coal-miner and you can't take the physical labor then you 耐えられない。

端.kun_translate: edge (always literal, never figurative) (of your seat, edge of the plank) As opposed to 縁（fuchi)  、　端 usually refers to ONE POINT on the edge, the most extreme point (i.e. edge of the cliff, tip of the peninsula)

包.kun_kanji:
(
を　・　に
)
つつ*む

泡.kun_translate: bubble, or a froth of hella bubbles

抱.kun_kanji:
(
を　or が
)
かか＊える

驚.kun_translate: to be shocked, surprised (驚いた！＝I was suprised!)

旬.kun_translate: meaning, when something is in season i.e. fruit

匂.kun_translate: Smell this! Does this milk smell fresh?

渇.kun_translate: something which is/should be wet , becomes dry: My eyes are dry. My throat is dry. Usually only used when you are thirsty, as in: のどが渇いてる!のど が かわいてる! I'm thirsty!

約.kun_translate: roughly speaking. Ish. 約9yards。 約3 days。
約.kun_kanji:
やく
(
XXX に or で
)

盗.kun_translate: to steal - in a sneaky, burglar way

温.kun_translate: also abbreviated to あったかい: warm thing (puppy, or puddle under your bed )

盛.kun_translate: a heaping bowl of food / a raging fire / something overflowing with solids (but not liquids - that's a different kanji with the same pronunciation! 漏る！！！）

溢.kun_translate: overflow (also you can use it if you are a lady who is, um, - it's the femenine equivalent of 'boioioioioioingggg!')

誉.kun_translate: compliment - no, wait, fuck it. Most dictionaries list both 褒める　and 誉める as kanji for 'homeru / compliment'. . . but in practice only the OTHER homeru (褒める)　is used! How's that for disambiguation?

挙.kun_translate: To metaphorically bring up something (an objection, a point) to give an example of , to cite or mention something. But also - irritatingly - to literally raise one's hand (Oo! Oo! I know ! I know!) However, if you're raising anything else BUT your hand, you have to use 上げる instead of 挙げる. Yeah, I know, I know. What can you do??

舟.kun_translate: boat.  Never used by itself - only used in jukugo about boat stuff (oars, masts, etc.)

狂.kun_translate: someone who is insane since childhood. Ted Bundy or whoever. They might seem normal at first.

独.kun_translate: Alone. Unlike the other hitori (一人)、　独り has a sort of lonlely value judgement on it. Like, 'He lives by himself' or 'She had to do the whole thing herself (since no one would help her)'

獲.kun_translate: get or obtain :Unlike the OTHER える(得る   ), 獲る   is used for　 hunting - the predator obtains prey. Also sometimes used about sports victories.

犯.kun_translate: commit or perpetrate - usually used with rape, so be careful how you use this.

印.kun_translate: a logo or symbol - as in a check mark on a list, or a cross, or the black flag logo

叩.kun_translate: beat (rain beats on the windowpane), hit (used specifically with drums), smack or slap (your Dad for mistakes in life)

卵.kun_translate: egg (used mostly by farmers and agriculture people) （ also means "beginner" , in the sense of "someone who might be really skilled at XXX but has not made their professional debut yet."  For instance, a great artist who has not had an exhibition or a genius photographer who has not published a photo-book yet.）

却.kun_translate: instead, all the more (better or worse)

範.translate: standard / the best way to do

腕.kun_translate: arm. Also, to be good at something, as in, "xxxの 腕 が いい!" "She's good at xxx!"

即.kun_translate: immediately XXX will happen. (you don't need a particle for this)

危.kun_translate: dangerous. Although, in a society where grown people spend their lives listening to loudspeakers telling them "Please watch your step," the notion of dangerous is broad enough to be meaningless.  If your friend is in someone's way on the sidewalk, you can't say, "Move over, dumbass!" you have to say 'Abunai!' and furtively point at the person they are about to run into. However, if you are walking and someone is in YOUR way, you can't say 'abunai' . In fact, there is nothing you can say.

抑.kun_translate: inhibit or suppress (a behavior or desire) (one's true feelings)  Also used about the Man oppressing or holding down The People in general.

迎.kun_translate: To pick someone up, like at the airport or bus stop!

報.kun_translate: to report (on tv or a newspaper)

阻.kun_translate: to stop the advance of something by physically obstructing it: The defensive lineman stopped the other team's football guy. The army checked the advance of the other army. Our vacation was stopped by the hurricane.

畳.kun_translate: traditional Japanese flooring made from woven straw

祈.kun_translate: to pray (used about Christians, but probably not Buddhists or Shinto), but also if you pray in class to pass a test, or pray "please let me catch that fly ball!") . . . .just like in English. 祈る Emphasizes the ACT of prayer, rather than the contents.

神.kun_translate: god or gods - almost never used by itself.

富.kun_translate: to be rich in XXX (i.e. This region is rich in timber. Tofu is rich in calcium.. . . .but not actual money usually)

乱.kun_translate: I mess shit up so it is disorderly

札.kun_translate: a label, nametag, small sign, etc.

腹.kun_translate: entrails! The kunyomi of his one is tricky because if it's written like this:　腹, it's pronounced はら、 but if it's written with the honorary 'お', like this: お腹、 then it's pronounced おなか。 Thus, this kanji is a COCK.

履.kun_translate: put on pants or shoes. That's right ； a crazy 1５-stroke kanji for a very basic act.(this must seem absurd to even Japanese because this kanji is usually KANA)

欲.kun_translate: I want it! (kind of a childish way to say it)

昇.kun_translate: ascend. (Planets, moons. People that go to heaven). Also people who take an elevator. Unlike the related word 登る, 昇る  implies that there is no effort on the part of the ascending person or thing.
昇.kun_kanji:
(
が or に
)
のぼ＊る

戒.kun_translate: warn someone to not do something

飛.kun_translate: 2 meanings: 1) I send something flying. 2) to skip a page, to skip a step in a process, to skip a turn in a game.

習.kun_translate: learn - but not like 'I learned Bob's last name!' Instead of single facts, 習う means to take lessons in something　－ karate, flower arranging. (BOOBOO: not used with math, science, or religion)

扇.kun_translate: to fan one's self (with a fan or one's hand)

散.kun_translate: to scatter, but in a GOOD way - seeds, information, sprinkles on a cupcake (also sometimes means, to distract someone's attention, which seems a little arbitrary).

譲.kun_translate: to hand something over (that you don't want to), to concede; to make a concession
譲.kun_kanji:
(
を or に
)
ゆず＊る

惜.kun_translate: close! Not as in, "Godzilla is close to Ultraman's size". Close, as in you throw a ball to a little kid and he drops it and you are like 'That was close! Almost!'

嬢.kun_translate: young lady - a bit formal.  Has the nuance of an eligible single daughter of a rich family. A flattering word used when picking up girls. Usually used on women up to 20 years old, but if you're 70 you can use it to a 40 year old single woman.
嬢.kun_kanji:
(
を
)
じょう
(
さん
)

横.kun_translate: side (BOOBOO: not left or right side, that's "gawa". Yoko is like I'm standing beside him, or, she's lying on her side, sideways.)

共.kun_kanji:
(
xxxと
)
とも
(
に yyy
)

並.kun_translate: ordinary, average xxx - when ordering food, it means, "I just want this ala carte"

巷.kun_translate: literally, it means a street. But it's usually used figuratively: word on the street is. . . . the streets are talking . . . his name rings out on the streets.

異.kun_translate: to differ according to xxx (similar to the ol' xxxによって違います）

暴.kun_translate: expose some bad thing in public - like a journalist or watchdog group would.

再.kun_translate: once again. For the second time

補.kun_translate: to suppliment - like 補充, but the nuance is that you are filling a vacancy. For instance, nutritional suppliment. Substitute teacher. Assist in the completion of something (I helped write the speech). To make up for (i.e. Mitsubishi bank loaned money to Toyota to make up for their shortfall) みつびし銀行はトヨタの赤字補いました。

構.kun_translate: to get into one's fighting stance, say, when a Samurai challenges one. Nowadays, usually used in the negative: 構えなくてもいい： don't be so nervous. relax.  Also sometimes means to pose as , to put on airs.

降.kun_translate: get off the bus/ taxi / train

悟.kun_translate: to realize　（that someone is following you around / that someone is lying to you), or have a spiritual enlightenment (like Buddha)

違.kun_translate: nuh-uh! Wrong! It's not like that at all!

偉.kun_translate: great, outstanding. As in 'a great painting' or 'a great show.'(p> It also means upper-class. Like 'We can't park in that parking spot - it's for erai people.'  A regular doctor is not erai, but the head surgeon of the hospital is erai. That kind of thing.

瞬.kun_translate: to blink, but also to flicker or twinkle。 Usually used as a adjective like, "またたく ほし" (twinkling star)

舞.kun_translate: to flutter or dance - like leaves in the wind. Not like a person doing the Smurf.

隣.kun_translate: next to- could be the seat next to yours, could be the house next to yours.

図.kun_translate: a fairly neutral word for 'to scheme or plan': 'The committee plans to raise interest rates.' It can be used for both good and bad schemes.

更.kun_translate: all over again, afresh, furthermore, in addition, besides.

硬.kun_translate: hardーalmost the same as the OTHER かたい （固）- hard like hard to break. If you want to say someone is stiff or stubborn or anal retentive, you'd have to use 固い, though.

使.kun_translate: use (a cement mixer, a video game controller, an AK)

便.kun_translate: news or communication from someone - a letter. A simple postcard now and again. Is that so much to ask? Mr. thinks-his-shit-don't-stink???

身.kun_translate: flesh (never used by itself - you wouldn't tell a hot dude, "nice み!!" as you leer at him. See below for examples.

謝.kun_translate: apologize　(BOOBOO: This is only used when describing actions after the fact. You wouldn't step on someone's toes and then say わたしはあやまります！)

窮.kun_translate: To be caught in a dillema, to have your back to the wall, to the point where there seems to be no hope. Almost never used.

他.kun_translate: other　－ another thing of the same type.

増.kun_translate: I increase something. (my bank balance, my muscles)

贈.kun_translate: give a present, or present someone with something rad (a scholarship, a knighthood). This is actually more similar to あげます, but I think it's a little more formal.

僧.kun_translate: a somewhat formal, official way to refer to a monk

宮.kun_translate: never used, except in last names, like Karin Amamiya, the labor rights activist.

追.kun_translate: chase - not just cat chases mouse, but also can mean to chase someone in a certain direction, for instance, to drive someone off, or to herd cattle.

遣.kun_translate: to be careful or give consideration to. Usually only used with the phrase 気を遣う、 but even then it's usually hiragana so who cares.

管.kun_translate: tube - rubber tube, plumbing pipe. Unlike the related kanji 筒, (cylinder) 管 can be bent or flexible.

営.kun_translate: to run a business - although it's not a formal word, いとなむ is usually used by older people. Normally Japanese people use 経営 instead.

栄.kun_translate: to flourish or become prosperous （usually used about communities - 'The Roman Empire flourished circa 1000 BC!!!')

学.kun_translate: 2 meanings: to learn something from a teacher. Also, to learn one random fact (not a whole subject). Unlike 勉強、 you can't 学ぶ by yourself.

覚.kun_translate: to memorize something. (i.e. for a test, or because you're a spy and you need to remember the password) or bear in mind (to be nicer to Grandma)

償.kun_translate: to compensate for, to make something up to someone

常.kun_translate: 2 meanings; 1-ordinarily, normally that is the case   2 - I do this all the time!

繕.kun_translate: two meanings. 1) to mend clothing, 2) to keep up appearances.

周.kun_translate: around here. All around me. All around it.(the emphasis is on 360 degrees - all around the circumference or perimeter of someone or something)

調.kun_translate: to ’check something out'. Not like years of research, but like to google it or try to find it on a map　－ to look up in a dictionary, to check tomorrow's weather report. To find out about the blood type of your favorite singer.

彫.kun_translate: carve, (also the verb for get a tattoo)

向.kun_translate: over there (it's also a slang, street term for 'those guys', the other side)

過.kun_translate: spend time on something fun, as like a hobby: spend time with loved ones, or with a rad book or an awesome pet.

薬.kun_translate: medicine.　薬を飲む　refers both to taking legal medcine and drugs.

眺.translate: look at for a long time while lost in thought
眺.kun_translate: to look at something for a long time, while lost in thought.

挑.kun_translate: to challenge someone or something to a win-or-lose battle. Sports or sometimes politics. （challenge the world champ a fight / challenge the system)
挑.kun_kanji:
(
に or を
)
いど＊む

書.kun_translate: write （BOOBOO:  write a word! To draw a picture, you'd use 描く　（かく）)

事.kun_translate: this one has a lot of meanings. Usually it means an action, as in 'You did a good thing there,' or 'You did a bad thing.'  Sometimes, it means person, though： かれ の こと が きらい! ('I can't stand his koto' means 'I can't stand him!')  わたし の こと を おぼえて うれしい!('Thank you for remembering my koto') means 'Thanks for remembering me.')

唐.kun_translate: You’ll only see this in the word 唐揚げ (kara-age), meaning ‘fried chicken’.

妻.kun_translate: my wife (人妻：ひとづま： a somewhat formal term for someone else's wife）

争.kun_translate: competition. Unlike the synonym 競争　（きょうそう）,　争う emphasizes a feeling of battle, a lack of rules, and only 争う can escalate to physical violence.

兼.kun_translate: to combine ｘｘｘ and ｙｙｙ, to double as (i.e. she's a maid who doubles as a bodyguard)
兼.kun_kanji:
(
xxx と　ｙｙｙ　を
)
か*ねる

嫌.kun_translate: Ewww! No way!(what YOU say in conversation)

延.kun_translate: to lengthen or extend (the life of a sick person)(the deadline) (your stay in a hotel). Also, to procrastinate. More used with time than physical length.

庭.kun_translate: a garden - (BOOBOO: not the kind that grows vegetables, which is 畑 (はたけ)。 A 庭 is like a garden in your front yard of flowers or decorative plants.)

聴.kun_translate: deliberately listen to for minutes at a time (to a preacher's sermon, a college lecture, a shitty techno song)

壊.kun_translate: I smash something , I break something.

劇.kun_translate: a play, a drama, a show

就.kun_translate: to have a job. (しごと に つく＝ to find a job)

之.kun_translate: 之 is an obsolete form of 'this'

乏.kun_translate: meager or scarce RESOURCES: forests, natural gas. Opportunities are scarce. Someone's experience or knowledge of a subject is scanty. Also can mean 'shoddy'

芝.kun_translate: grass , usually used like this：芝生

基.kun_translate: foundation or basis (the manga is based on the anime which was based on the videogame which was based on a true story)

甚.kun_translate: egregious (error), outrageous (impudence!), gross (negligence), ungodly (amount of sebum on the linoleum)

勘.kun_translate: a hunch, as in 'かん が ある.' ('I have a hunch . . ')

堪.kun_translate: tolerate, in a moral sense. Can't tolerate racism or "that kind of conduct."

鈍.kun_translate: dull like not sharp (not dull as in dumb)

逆.kun_translate: to counter-react, to do the opposite of what you're supposed

似.kun_translate: to resemble; to take after someone - usually used of parents and children, rather than 'Hey he looks like Afrika Bambatta!' Usually it is used in one of 2 idioms: すこしも にてない、 or よくにてる)
似.kun_kanji:
(
が or に
)
に*る

承.kun_translate: (business - speak) What you say when you have heard and understood a proposal. Does not neccesairly mean you agree. Another example of Japanese deliberate ambiguity.

暇.kun_translate: free - not busy.  People sometimes use this sarcastically, as if to say, "He has too much time on his hands." or "Get a life." 暇だね！

巡.kun_translate: to travel around, or (metaphorically) to come round: the seasons rotate, leap year comes round once every four years.

災.kun_translate: a personal misfortune: house burned down, father had a stroke

誤.kun_translate: to make a mistake- Basically this is a more formal version of 間違える! Used by older folks instead of 間違える, but you can use it if you're talking about a miscalculation or if you took the wrong course of action/ a failed policy.

偽.kun_translate: a small deception, a white lie. Lying about your age. Lying on your resume (BOOBOO: not to be confused with the related terms 　だます(decieve to be mean)　 and　あざむく (criminal fraud)

隔.kun_translate: to partition, to separate: separate the class into "gifted" and "not gifted" students. Partition the room using folding screens. Divide the property between people. 5mずつ隔てて： every five feet (there's a pillar or fencepost).

拝.kun_translate: literally, to pray at a Shinto temple(BOOBOO: not used for Christians, Buddhists, etc.). Figuratively, to worship the ground someone walks on.
